revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}} {{infobox military unit |unit_name=7th Signal Regiment |image=[[File:Special wireless group.jpg|300px]] |caption=Troops of the Australian Special Wireless Group marching through their camp at Kalinga, Queensland, in July 1945. |dates=1940–present |country={{flag|Australia|23px}} |allegiance= |branch=[[Australian Army]] |type=[[Signals intelligence]] |role= |size=~ 250 personnel |command_structure=[[6th Brigade (Australia)|6th Brigade]], [[Forces Command (Australia)|Forces Command]] |garrison=[[Cabarlah, Queensland]] |garrison_label= |nickname= |patron= |motto= |colors= |colors_label= |march= |mascot= |equipment= |equipment_label= |battles=[[World War II]]
[[Malayan Emergency]]
[[Indonesia–Malaysia confrontation|Confrontation]]
[[Vietnam War]]
[[Iraq War|Iraq]]
[[War in Afghanistan (2001-present)|Afghanistan]] |anniversaries= |decorations= |battle_honours= |battle_honours_label= |disbanded= |flying_hours= |website= |commander1= |commander1_label= |commander2= |commander2_label= |commander3= |commander3_label= |commander4= |commander4_label= |notable_commanders= |identification_symbol= |identification_symbol_label= |identification_symbol_2= |identification_symbol_2_label= |identification_symbol_3= |identification_symbol_3_label= |identification_symbol_4= |identification_symbol_4_label= }} The '''7th Signal Regiment''' is an [[Australian Army]] [[signals intelligence]] (SIGINT) unit. Drawing lineage from the Australian Special Wireless Group (ASWG), which was raised during [[World War II]], the regiment's history includes service in the Allied campaigns in [[Battle of Greece|Greece]], on [[Battle of Crete|Crete]] and in [[Syria-Lebanon campaign|Syria]] before taking part in the fighting against the Japanese in [[New Guinea campaign|New Guinea]]. After the war, the ASWG was redesignated the 101 Wireless Regiment, deploying detachments overseas during the [[Malayan Emergency]] and [[Indonesia–Malaysia confrontation|Confrontation]]. In the mid-1960s, the unit became the 7th Signals Regiment, taking part in the [[Vietnam War]]. The unit is currently part of the [[6th Brigade (Australia)|6th Brigade]]. ==World War II== The regiment traces its lineage back to a unit that was raised as part of the [[Second Australian Imperial Force]] (2nd AIF) during [[World War II]]. The Australian Special Wireless Group (ASWG) was formed as signals intelligence group on 18 May 1942 at [[Bonegilla, Victoria]]. With a war establishment of 1,000 personnel, the ASWG was raised out of a smaller unit, No. 4 Australian Special Wireless Section, which had been raised at [[Seymour, Victoria]], in 1940 and had served in [[Egypt]], [[Battle of Greece|Greece]], [[Battle of Crete|Crete]], and [[Syria-Lebanon campaign|Syria]], before being withdrawn back to Australia after Japan's entry into the war.{{cite journal |author =Dewar, A. |author2 =Watt, E. |author3 =Murray, D. |last-author-amp =yes |title=The History of the Australian Special Wireless Group |journal=Signalman |volume=Spring / Summer |year=2002 |pages=42–45 |issn= }} From August 1942, females were also recruited into the ASWG. Personnel undertook four months of training, before being formed into [[Section (military)|sections]] and deployed to various locations in remote parts of Australia or in [[New Guinea campaign|New Guinea]]. The ASWG was headquartered at [[Kalinga, Queensland|Kalinga]], in Brisbane during the war and eventually 11 field sections were raised in total.{{cite web |url=http://www.ozatwar.com/sigint/aswg.htm |title= Australian SpecialWireless Group, AIF, in Australia During World War 2 |publisher=Oz At War |accessdate=2 June 2013}} By the end of the war, the ASWG had around 4,300 personnel. Parts of the group were later absorbed into the [[Central Bureau]].{{cite book | author1=Hillier, Jean | title=No Medals in this Unit |year=1996 | publisher=J. Hillier |location=Mundulla, South Australia | isbn=978-0-646-27180-4}}{{cite book | author1=McCue, W. J | title=Spook Stuff | year=1996 | publisher=J. McCue | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/23291566 |oclc=38758603 |location=Griffiths, Australian Capital Territory}}{{cite news| url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/features/spy-twins-top-secret-war/story-e6frg6z6-1226337478574 | first=Sarah | last=Lucas | title=Spy twins' top-secret war | date=25 April 2012 | work=The Australian |accessdate=16 September 2013}} ==Post 1945== After the conclusion of hostilities, the ASWG was relocated to [[Cabarlah, Queensland]], {{convert|12|mi|km}} north of [[Toowoomba, Queensland|Toowoomba]]. In February 1947, it was redesignated the "101 Wireless Regiment", with an authorised strength of two officers and 22 other ranks. Over the next two years, the regiment was expanded and between 1951 and 1959, the regiment deployed a detachment to Malaya in support of Commonwealth forces deployed during the [[Malayan Emergency]]. During the early 1960s, the regiment deployed to Borneo during [[Indonesia–Malaysia confrontation|Confrontation]], intercepting and decoding Indonesian communications. A further name change came in December 1964, when it became the 7th Signal Regiment, subsequently deploying a [[troop]] – 547 Troop – as part of [[Military history of Australia during the Vietnam War|Australia's contribution to the Vietnam War]]. The unit continues to exist within the Australian Army today as part of the [[6th Brigade (Australia)|6th Brigade]], providing an electronic warfare capability. From the 1990s, the regiment provided support for Australian Army deployments to [[United Nations Assistance Mission for Rwanda|Rwanda]], [[Multinational Force and Observers|Sinai]], [[INTERFET|East Timor]], [[Peace Monitoring Group|Bougainville]], [[RAMSI|Solomon Islands]], [[Australian contribution to the 2003 invasion of Iraq|Iraq]] and [[Operation Slipper|Afghanistan]]. It is currently based at Borneo Barracks, at Cabarlah and has an establishment of around 250 personnel. The majority of its personnel are members of the [[Royal Australian Corps of Signals]].{{cite web |url=http://www.army.gov.au/Who-we-are/Divisions-and-Brigades/Forces-Command/6th-Brigade/7th-Signal-Regiment |title=7th Signal Regiment |publisher=Australian Army |accessdate=2 June 2013}} In June 1995, then Governor-General Bill Hayden was the Reviewing Officer for the regiment's 48th birthday parade held at Borneo Barracks, Cabarlah.{{cite web |url=https://www.awm.gov.au/collection/P06965.001 |title=Image: Governor General Bill Hayden presenting an award during the 7th Signal Regiment 48th birthday parade – June 1995 |publisher=Australian War Memorial |accessdate=17 August 2015}}{{cite web |url=https://www.awm.gov.au/collection/P06965.002 |title=Image: Governor General Bill Hayden walking with Rwanda and Sinai award recipients after the 7 Sig 48th Birthday parade |publisher=Australian War Memorial |accessdate=17 August 2015}} As of 2016, the 7th Signal Regiment comprised the following sub-units:{{cite news|last1=Bree|first1=Max|title=Signals intelligence at the cutting edge|url=http://armynews.realviewdigital.com/?iid=145050#folio=22|accessdate=21 August 2016|work=Army|agency=Department of Defence|date=11 August 2016|page=22}} *71st Squadron *72nd Squadron *73rd Squadron *Operations Support Squadron ==See also== * [[Signals intelligence in modern history#Australian Army]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== *{{cite journal|last1=Blaxland|first1=John|title=The Role of Signals Intelligence in Australian Military Operations, 1939–72|journal=Australian Army Journal|date=2005|volume=II|issue=2|pages=203–216|url=http://www.army.gov.au/Our-future/Publications/Australian-Army-Journal/Past-editions/~/media/Files/Our%20future/LWSC%20Publications/AAJ/2005Autumn/19-TheRoleOfSignalsIntelli.pdf|publisher=Land Warfare Studies Centre |location=Canberra, Australian Capital Territory|issn=1448-2843}} [[Category:Signals intelligence agencies]] [[Category:Military units and formations of the Australian Army]]
